messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "CÃ©dric Beust â" " <cbeust@...>
wrote:
>
> On 9/16/06, Marvin Toll <MarvinToll@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > 1) There are contexts where both an OOP solution and a
declarative
> > solution is effective. I happen to prefer an OOP solution as a
> > first choice. ("test" vs "@Test")
>
>
> I'm not sure why you think that being forced to have a method name
start
> with "test" is OOP?

MDT ---> I agree the conversation is a bit muddled here. It is the
combination of inheritance + "test" that provides the method
invocation solution. The approach stands in (stylistic) contrast to
the two popular declarative solutions - using a descriptor document
or an annotation (in this case to cause method invocation).

In other words, I don't want to "throw out" an OOP inheritance
solution just because it also includes notating a method with "test".

> 2) What I'm not prepared to accept, is an assertion that
> > declarative programming is "better" (when there are two workable
> > choices) by virtue of its existence.
>
>
> It is better in this case, because munging your method names so
that a tool
> can pick them off is clearly better addressed with annotations.

MDT ---> Cedric - I do (respectfully) disagree with you on this
point. The term "optimization for code completion" attempts to
capture the notion that naming of Classes and Methods can be done in
a manner that provides more (immediate) clarity within an IDE
context.

In an earlier post - you referred to it as adding "adding metadata
to that method" name. In addition to code completion, having all
like method names begin with a prescribed verb is useful for sorting
methods. For instance, in Eclipse when one types 'Ctrl-o' followed
by 'test' - you very quickly list the test methods in a class vs.
supporting (perhaps private?) methods.

I have not seen alot said about "optimization for code completion" -
as an example the following link documents a specific API
promoting "exists", "read", "register" for transparent persistence
related operations.

http://gtcgroup.com/joppa/The.Road.to.Joppa.html#JoppaCRUD

An advanced verification technique is to reflectively interrogate
method names on functional classes (during unit testing) to ensure
they conform to either platform, corporate or application method
naming conventions.

The strength of your conviction in this area is causing me to
wonder. Am I the only Java "guy" that finds benefit (on a fifteen
developer project on two continents) in having a test method begin
with he word "test" - or, a callback method begin with "pre"
or "post" - or, a transparent persistence registration begin
with "register"???

Or said more simply - I find value in having test methods begin
with "test" even if not required by the invocation mechanism. And
if there is a (platform or corporate or application) naming
convention I like it enforced in a testing context.

> In the case of @Ignore - no
> > question about it (in my mind) - that is a problem begging for a
> > declarative solution.
>
>
> Following your logic, shouldn't you rename testFoo() to ignoreFoo
() then?
>

Sure. Except for the fact that "test" is a long-term perscription
and "ignore" is (presumably) transitory. The nuances around which
capability is appropriatly declared and which capability is
appropriately inherited are more subtle than a verb study.

In this case, "ignore" is a contextual assignment. It might
mean, "ignore until I get this test method working". Whereas "test"
means "always test" unless declared otherwise. "Ignore" is
(conceptual) override of "test". They are not peers - so, a
different stylistic implementation might be warranted.
